item.title: The State of Sia, April 2023
item.dc:creator: Steve
item.content:encoded:
Weâ€™re back with the State of Sia, a monthly installment looking at development and team updates for The Sia Foundation.

And so ends the first quarter of 2023. In a feat of being Technically Correct, we have indeed released the renterd beta that weâ€™ve been chatting about for a while, right on time in the late hours of March 31stÂ :)

Featuring new architecture that the dev team has been working incredibly hard on, and a beautiful re-imagined UI/UX from Alex, this is our first step towards the future of the Foundation. Our newly-built apps for renting, hosting, and wallet functions will continue to march towards full releases. The plan right now is to have a hostd beta, and a renterd full release, in the comingÂ months.

We canâ€™t wait for you to try themÂ out.

Switching gears, a recent development affecting the Sia ecosystem was the announcement from Bittrex that they are shutting down US operations, with the last full day to withdraw your funds being April 29, 2023. Weâ€™ve put together a brief guide for navigating this, as well as what it means for the broader Sia network,Â here.

Finally, while we mention this later I want to call something out right now. Weâ€™ve updated sia.tech with a new roadmap for the Foundationâ€™s work. This is a mid to high level look at core Sia development, both current and future. It focuses on the big projects weâ€™re working on, what weâ€™ve got planned next, and includes an activity feed from all of our publicÂ repos.

It will be updated at least once a quarter to reflect changes in our priorities or to recognize significant accomplishments. This roadmap is important for a few reasonsâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s something easy to point new users, potential partners, and exchanges to. The activity feed gives a quick look at development that might otherwise fly under the radar. And it just looks really cool. Check it out over at sia.tech/roadmap.

I was personally really impressed with how quickly we put this together. What started out as a tentative request in an informal meeting turned into something real, and significant, in less than two weeks. And thatâ€™s with a whole bunch of other important things goingÂ on.

Thatâ€™ll do it for me, letâ€™s get on to the goodÂ stuff.

Development

All public repos can be foundÂ here.

renterd

renterd will be our new stand-alone renter. The renterd repo is currently public and can be found here, and the app is available inÂ beta.

  • Profiled and benchmarked the upload and download performance in renterd. A new benchmarking tool was written for this purposeÂ (Link)
  • Autopilot can be configured with multiple workers used for maintenance (Link)
  • Tracking more contract info (Link),Â (Link)
  • Improved object search endpoints (Link)
  • Calculated transaction outflowÂ (Link)
  • Added endpoint for listing all contract setsÂ (Link)
  • Host prices are taken into account when scoring themÂ (Link)
  • Added Autopilot endpoints to fetch host info including their scoreÂ (Link)
  • Added testnet support via build flagÂ (Link)
  • Improved general working condition of the worker and autopilot by improving logging and fixing some small bugs (Link), (Link), (Link), (Link),Â (Link)
  • Favour fast hosts when downloading (Link)
  • Fixed docker container not shutting down cleanlyÂ (Link)
  • Fixed files becoming unhealthy when corresponding contract is renewedÂ (Link)
  • Added a retry when applying failed db transactions (Link)

renterd ui

The repos containing the various UIs being worked on can be foundÂ here.

  • The configuration settings now include host block heightÂ leeway.
  • renterd now has a syncing flow that shows blockchain sync progress and allows the user to manually connect more peers and manage settings.
  • The Files breadcrumb nav now scrolls to show the working directory when necessary.
  • Host explorer now includes a block status column and the hover tooltip explains how each list contributed to being blocked orÂ not.
  • Apps now have embed specific build flags, embedded apps do not show a server field atÂ login.
  • The host explorer now supports filtering hosts by block status andÂ address.
  • The global command menu now has emptyÂ states.
  • Contract spending is now displayed as a negativeÂ value.
  • The file health indicator now shows a breakdown of shards per slab onÂ hover.
  • Data loading and filtering states have been refined across all features.
  • The file explorer now lists parent directory for traversing up aÂ level.
  • The host explorer now features quick filters and actions for each hostÂ row.
  • Contracts, hosts, and files tables now include an errorÂ state.
  • Files now show their current health based on how many data shards have active contracts.
  • The contracts explorer now supports filtering by address and publicÂ key.
  • renterd now supports searching for files, access the feature from the Files actions menu or through the global commandÂ menu.
  • The files explorer now supports navigation, directory creation, file deletion, andÂ more.
  • File paths are now linkable and reflected in the appÂ URL.
  • The blocklist manager now suggests adding well-known spam addresses to blocklist and shows whether renterd has any active contracts with hosts matching these addresses.
  • The hosts feature now shows autopilot score and score breakdown columns.
  • The gouging config now includes min max collateral.
  • The files feature now has a view configuration menu.
  • The apps are now built into Go modules exposing static assets as an embed.FS.
  • The hosts feature now shows whether autopilot considers the host usable based on the scoring criteria. If the host is unusable, the reasons areÂ listed.
  • Fixed an issue where siacoin config values were being sent as decimalÂ strings.
  • Host, contract, and file explorer action menus are now all accessed via an icon on the far left of eachÂ row.
  • The hosts feature now allows filtering to hosts with active contracts.
  • renterd now supports allowlist and blocklist management, accessible from the global command menu or the hostsÂ page.
  • All autopilot features are now disabled and hidden if renterd is running with autopilot disabled.
  • The contract timeline now shows points for contract revisions andÂ proofs.
  • Fix a z-index Safari bug that would clip the action dropdown in the AppLayout.
  • PaginatorUnknownTotal now displays correct last pageÂ values.
  • The Table components column sizing has been improved.
  • Lock and sync screens now remember and redirect back to the previousÂ page.

hostd

hostd is the app youâ€™ll be using to rent out your excess storage space to the Sia network. The hostd repo isÂ public.

  • Added sign and notarize to publish workflow so macOS users can run binariesÂ (Link)
  • Added an OpenAPI spec so users can generate API clients in any languageÂ (Link)
  • Separated the host and wallet private keys to make it possible for hosts to migrate from siadÂ (Link)
  • Added a "rejected" status to contracts that do not make it on chain (Link),Â (Link)
  • Fixed performance issues in volume manager when dealing with large volumes (Link), (Link),Â (Link)
  • Added debug logging for slow queries, this will make it easier to track down performance bottlenecks (Link)
  • Added filtering to the contracts endpointÂ (Link)

core

The core repo is public and can be foundÂ here.

  • Added network parameterization. This allows us to specify different network parameters, such as the target block time, without having to recompile the entire program as in siadÂ (Link)
  • Added gateway protocol support. This is a first step towards replacing the siad gateway module; much of the remaining code is already written, but uncommitted. renterd, hostd, and walletd will make use of this code to communicate with other Sia nodesÂ (Link)
  • Added tests for the consensus code in v1 core. These basically check that bad transactions are rejected (inputs > outputs, double spends, invalid contracts, etc) (Link),Â (Link)
  • Added the RHP3 renew RPC protocol objectsÂ (Link)

website

  • The website now features the Sia Foundationâ€™s new roadmapÂ (Link)
  • The website now features a feed of GitHub development activityÂ (Link)
  • Added docs.sia.tech to the site map and adjusted categorization.

Ledger

  • Worked on porting the existing Ledger app to the new Ledger StaxÂ (Link)

Thatâ€™s allÂ folks

This was a big update. Iâ€™m sure next time around weâ€™ll have more to say about the renterd beta, and the progress weâ€™ve made towards the rest of our app suite. April also takes us to MIT Bitcoin, so weâ€™ll have a recap of all the action fromÂ Boston.

Until nextÂ time!

Discord, Email

Steve

item.title: PSA: Bittrex is shutting down US operations
item.dc:creator: Steve
item.content:encoded:
Last Friday, Bittrex announced that they will be shutting down US operations effective April 30, 2023 at 12PM PDT/3PMÂ EDT.

First thingsÂ first

If you hold Siacoins, any other cryptocurrency, or any fiat in your Bittrex wallet you need to move those funds out to a safe account that you control. I never miss an opportunity to remind folksâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot your keys, not your crypto. Keeping cryptocurrency in an exchange wallet is one of the easiest ways to lose it. Fortunately, Bittrex has provided ample time for you to transfer your funds, so make use of this opportunity.

A little closer toÂ home

Now that thatâ€™s out of the way, Iâ€™d like to talk about how this affects The Sia Foundation and ourÂ users.

The loss of Bittrex is an unfortunate event for Sia users in the United States. Bittrex provided a reliable way to get Siacoins so users could use them for their purpose of purchasing and renting storage on the Sia network. It was also the second largest exchange for trading Siacoins by daily volume, so a not-insignificant amount of users will be affected.

Fortunately, Kraken is still available for US users. Kraken is consistently the most-used US exchange for trading Siacoins by daily volume, and has been a reputable resource for the community. For now, we recommend that Sia users in the US create a Kraken account for acquiring Siacoins to rentÂ storage.

The Foundation is also looking into options to expand the footprint of US exchanges that offer Siacoins. Weâ€™ll have more info on this as it becomes available.

Links andÂ info

Learn how to set up our official Sia wallet, and follow these steps to make an address to transfer your SiacoinsÂ over.

A full timeline of the Bittrex shutdown can be foundÂ here.

For any other questions, please reach out in ourÂ Discord.

Sia is a blockchain-based storage network that allows users to store their files in a fully decentralized way that is safer and less expensive than traditional centralized options.

item.title: Grants Program Update, March 2023
item.dc:creator: Steve
item.content:encoded:
The Sia Foundation has grant funding available for community contributors! The Grants Program was created to fund research, development, developer tools, and anything else that will support and further our mission of user-owned data while enriching the Sia ecosystem.

Just design a proposal that meets our requirements, submit to our forums, and wait for review by our grants committee. If your grant gets approved, youâ€™re on your way to creating the next great project on the Sia storageÂ network.

Check out our site for moreÂ info.

The Current State ofÂ Grants

The committee reviewed one new grant and checked in on the progress reports from all our existing grantees. Weâ€™ve also got another new one to take a look at, which arrived just late enough for the committee to need additional time toÂ review.

New Proposal: Rocket Web3Â Game

Link

What isÂ it?

A simple space game with a crypto marketplace and earningsÂ system.

Grant Status

Not approved

Updates

Our first game idea had an interesting premise, but a lacking proposal. While the committee is open to reconsidering, the committee needed to better understand how Sia would be integrated, better budget justification, and a bit more detailed breakdown of the timeline andÂ goals.

Progress Reports

When you accept a grant, you commit to update the Foundation and community once a month with a progress report detailing your work done, milestones youâ€™ve met, and what youâ€™ll work on next. Hereâ€™s a quick recap of some of the latest progress reports weâ€™ve received from previous grantees.

Fabstir

Link

  • Set up local MiniKubes test media player/transcoder infrastructures.
  • Successfully uploaded a video to the media player cluster, which was then uploaded toÂ S5.
  • Added authorization token functionality to the tus_client Rust native code, enabling Redsolverâ€™s code snippet to upload files with authorization.

Alphaday

Link

Alphaday is 99% complete, and the committee has been seeing internal versions prior to release. This will likely be our first fully completeÂ grant.

Lume Web

Link

  • Handshake syncing and querying fully working in theÂ browser
  • Significant work has been done on the DHT communication as well as the related client libraries that are used for DHT andÂ DNS
  • Redundancy/resiliency and connection retries/reconnecting were added to the different layers up to the HNS moduleÂ itself
  • Has started researching and implementing IPFS
  • Started on a website rebranding and redesign via contracting

Sia Satellite

Link

  • Contracts can now be formed using renterd and the satellite
  • Able to lock a part of the balance when a contract is formed and unlocking it when itÂ ends
  • Made some web portal improvements and bugÂ fixes
  • Next: contract renewals and further integration withÂ renterd

Coming Next

We encourage the community to provide their feedback and ask questions on the Sia Forum! Community contribution and input is the best way to push proposals and projects to the nextÂ level.

You can see the list of all proposals here, and our proposal requirements here. See you nextÂ month!

Weâ€™re back with the State of Sia, a monthly installment looking at development and team updates for The Sia Foundation.

As we head into the end of Q1, weâ€™re moving towards an important time for the Foundation. Work on our new releases has been progressing steadilyâ€Šâ€”â€Šand weâ€™re rapidly approaching the point where weâ€™ll have betas of our new software available. As a non-dev with a bit of technical know-how, itâ€™s an absolute pleasure to be able to see the progress that is coming from our dev team. This is the stuff that will define the direction of Sia for the next few years, and we hope that youâ€™ll love the work that weâ€™ve done (and remember that they are betasÂ ğŸ™‚).

The Grants Program has been moving along well, with a steady stream of proposals from grant-hopefuls as well as internal process improvements on our end to keep things running smoothly. Weâ€™ll expand more on those process improvements in the next grants blog postâ€Šâ€”â€ŠIâ€™ve even been considering a separate post talking about how we run things overÂ there.

Next month youâ€™ll likely see some very minor changes to our quarterly report, but weâ€™ll call those out when theyÂ happen.

And thatâ€™s enough exposition, letâ€™s take a look at our work thisÂ month.

Development

All public repos can be foundÂ here.

renterd

renterd will be our new stand-alone renter. The renterd repo is currently public and can be found here, and the app is expected to be released in beta by the end ofÂ Q1.

  • Fixed a deadlock in the workerÂ (Link)
  • Fixed panics due to integer overflows (Link)
  • Fixed ongoing uploads failing when contracts renew midway throughÂ (Link)
  • Support for MySQLÂ (Link)
  • MaxCollateral and RemainingStorage now play into host scoresÂ (Link)
  • Added some leeway before we start migrating data to avoid excessive repairsÂ (Link)
  • Correctly handled SIGTERM to allow for graceful shutdowns in dockerÂ (Link)
  • Autopilot now keeps Ephemeral Accounts filledÂ (Link)
  • Default gouging settings are a bit stricter nowÂ (Link)
  • Added runtime profiling (Link)
  • Added allowlist (selecting a pool of hosts to form contracts with)Â (Link)
  • Improved renter shutdown handlingÂ (Link)
  • Improved session timeout handlingÂ (Link)
  • Added a seed command to generate a new recovery phraseÂ (Link)
  • Used ephemeral accounts for downloads
  • Extended documentation
  • Fixed a non-deterministic erasure coding bug which caused randomÂ panics

renterd UI

  • The contracts feature now shows a timeline visualization for active contracts
  • The contracts feature now shows and supports pagination and filtering active contracts.
  • Contracts are now filterable by expiryÂ date.
  • Contracts are now filterable by renewalÂ date.
  • The contracts filtering options are now accessible through the global cmd+kÂ menu.
  • The Hosts feature now supports pagination and shows host info, scan, interaction, and uptime information.
  • The configuration page now includes the max storage price gougingÂ setting.
  • The Autopilot settings were updated with the latest options including contractÂ set.
  • The Files page now shows an onboarding/empty state when there are noÂ files.

hostd

hostd is the app youâ€™ll be using to rent out your excess storage space to the SiaÂ network.

  • Added structured logging. Makes it easier to parse log events and determine the source ofÂ issues.
  • Migrated RHP3 to use the new volume and contractÂ managers
  • Fixed wallet bugs causing transaction displayÂ issues
  • Added RenewedFrom field to contracts to make it possible to track contracts acrossÂ renewals
  • Improved shutdown for allÂ modules
  • Fixed issues with volume reloading and unavailable volumes.
    docs

walletd

walletd will be the place to store your Siacoins.

Ported to core/types instead of siad/types: (Link), (Link), andÂ (Link).

core

The core repo is currently public and can be foundÂ here.

  • Added RHP (renter-host protocol) packages to core. This allows renterd and hostd (and any other project) to share a single implementation of the RHP, rather than maintaining separate, possibly-incompatible versionsÂ (Link)
  • Fixed compatibility issues between core and siad. Lets hostd and renterd talk to siad (Link), (Link), (Link), (Link), andÂ (Link)
  • Implemented a blockchain manager and database in core. Previously, core had all of the bits and pieces required to perform Sia consensus, but it lacked an "engine" that could actually ingest blocks, apply the resulting state changes, and track the heaviest chain. This functionality was tested by successfully processing the full Sia blockchain (Link)
  • Fixed math for computing new collateral upon renew in coreÂ (Link)
  • Fixed some encoding/decoding issues in the (refactored) rhpv3 protocolÂ (Link)
  • Added Source to delayed outputs. This makes it easier for wallets and explorers to display non-transactions like contract payoutsÂ (Link)
  • Added support for testnet constants in core. This is a small but important change that allows core to be used on the testnetÂ (Link)
  • Added testnet tax Hardfork override. Enables hostd and renterd testnet buildsÂ (Link)
  • Added some consensus tests after core was updatedÂ (Link)

docs

  • Add linux setup guide for hostsÂ (Link)

jape

jape is what we use to check that the API routes between client/server are consistent.

  • Added support for strings in query parameters. Fixes API panics in hostd and renterdÂ (Link)

website

  • The website now loads fonts with zero layout shift, this optimization also applies to all otherÂ apps.
  • The website now shows the correct pronounciation of Sia at top of the homepage.
  • Code and content changes were made to the homepage to improve SEO and new user experienceâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe Grants program is now prominently featured on the homepage.
  • Migrate from nginx to caddy for serving website and otherÂ apps.

core UI libraries

  • ContractTimeline now shows the proofÂ window.
  • ContractTimeline component is now aware of both block height and timeÂ units.
  • Added PaginatorKnownTotal and PagniatorUnknownTotal.
  • Fixed xxs TextÂ size.
  • Added useClientFilters.
  • Button now has active and inactive variants.
  • The tailwind theme now supports text fill and shadowÂ fill.

  • Add base MenuItem components.
  • Added a max length of 200 characters to toast messages.

  • Add useSettingsUpdate hook for PUT /settings.

Other Foundation Happenings

Advent of CodeÂ merch

Weâ€™ve received the shirts for our Advent of Code participants! If you completed at least seven days during our December event, contact me at steve@sia.tech if you havenâ€™t heard from meÂ already.

Grants Program

The proposals continue! After approving Messariâ€™s grant and recommending that Log Store re-apply at a later date, the committee recently reviewed another two, with a third and fourth on the docket for this week. The committee approved our biggest grant yet, and weâ€™re incredibly excited to fill you with the latest update over at blog.sia.tech.

Our Grants Program page on sia.tech was also updated to include a Grantee FAQ to answer some common questions that might come up during and after your grant proposal.

If you think youâ€™ve got a great idea to benefit the Sia ecosystem, submit your proposal over at forum.sia.tech.

Thatâ€™s allÂ folks

As we look towards the end of Q1 and the beginning of Q2, we can be proud of the quiet progress weâ€™ve made. The growth of our grants program, the focus on scalability in our new apps, and the quality of both our team and community are all we need to continue driving toÂ success.

Until nextÂ time!

Discord, Email

Steve

item.title: Grants Program Update, February 2023
item.dc:creator: Steve
item.content:encoded:
The Sia Foundation has grant funding available for community contributors! The Grants Program was created to fund research, development, developer tools, and anything else that will support and further our mission of user-owned data while enriching the Sia ecosystem.

Just design a proposal that meets our requirements, submit to our forums, and wait for review by our grants committee. If your grant gets approved, youâ€™re on your way to creating the next great project on the Sia storageÂ network.

Check out our site for moreÂ info.

The Current State ofÂ Grants

Weâ€™re continuing to see new and interesting proposals at a steady pace. Over the past month we reviewed four new submissions, approving one, declining another, requesting more information from the third, and recommending the final wait and re-propose at a laterÂ date.

The committee also made an important decision after approving Alphaday, a Sia news and on-chain data aggregator. They had committed to open source their data streams, but also asked about difficulties open-sourcing non-critical dev components like their front-end. The committeeâ€™s conclusion was the following: Projects can use closed-source components, but canâ€™t develop closed-source code.

This is of course subject to review and may change at a later date, but will serve as a target for us moving forward and will hopefully not relegate otherwise great (or fun!) projects to an unnecessary denial.

Weâ€™ve also added a Grant FAQ to our site to answer some common questions about theÂ program.

New Proposal: Messari Quarterly Reports

Link

What isÂ it?

â€œWe are proposing that Messari provide Sia with in-depth data analytics and research. This would serve to better inform existing stakeholders as well as attract new ones. while building out the open-source data infrastructure for the community.
These reports would live as free resources on Messari and would be distributed through our newsletter, social channels, and third-party distribution partners including Bloomberg, S&P Global, and Refinitiv.â€
-Messari

Grant Status

Approved

Updates

The committee was very excited to have not just a research-centric proposal, but one from Messari. They agreed that these reports would benefit the ecosystem, and Messari has a large audience and a strong track record of doing thorough research.

Between the potentially massive reach of the reports, and the meticulous attention to detail for which Messari is known, these reports will provide an excellent resource for Sia community newcomers and veterans for years toÂ come.

New Proposal: Siaâ€™s ArabicÂ Library

Link

What isÂ it?

Content creation and outreach for Arabic-speaking communities.

Grant Status

Declined

Updates

The committee was concerned with being able to assess the outcome without having anyone on the team who can speak the language, and our inability to continue serving whatever community might arise from thisÂ effort.

We actually receive requests for this type of work fairly often, but this was the first to come via a grant proposal. We love the idea of expanding the community reach of Sia and will consider if this is something we might want to move on in the future. This just wasnâ€™t the right fit quiteÂ yet.

New Proposal: MemoryÂ Gardens

Link

What isÂ it?

Secure, archivable service for all personal and individual contentÂ types.

Grant Status

More information requested

Updates

The committee is concerned about the lack of risk definition in the proposal. A risk identified by the committee was the need to hire developers for this projectâ€Šâ€”â€Šhaving to onboard brand-new developer talent can be costly and time-consuming. Details regarding the ability of the current team to deliver would also be helpful, such as links to actual work done in the form of GitHub profiles or something else.

It seems like the team is currently developing on Arweave, and an understanding of the differences between Arweave and Sia would be an important consideration. The open source commitment is also unclear in the proposal. The idea seems very cool, and weâ€™re excited to see if the Memory Gardens team can supply the requested info.

New Proposal: LogÂ Store

Link

What isÂ it?

A decentralised event log storage solution that they want to integrate with the Sia network for storage of these eventÂ logs.

Grant Status

Recommended to re-submit at a laterÂ date

Updates

The Log Store team submitted an excellent, well-detailed proposal. Upon review, the committee requested more info from the team and was concerned about the timeline and existing state of development with the project and its Arweave integration.

The Log Store team responded and said that they can create a new grant proposal exclusively for the Sia storage module component of Log Store after the alpha has been released. The Grants Committee agreed with this and is looking forward to hearing from the Log StoreÂ team!

Coming Next

We already have a brand new proposal to take a look at during our next meeting. We encourage the community to provide their feedback and ask questions on the Sia Forum so the committee can gauge community interest and to help engage the applicant should they not come from the Sia ecosystem.

You can see the list of all proposals here, and our proposal requirements here. See you nextÂ month!

Steve

Weâ€™re back with the State of Sia, a monthly installment looking at development and team updates for The Sia Foundation.

The holiday break didnâ€™t slow us down at all. January was chock full of progress on our updated apps and new tools for the network. The Grants Program continued forward with new proposals and updates to our processes, and the Operations team settled into a number of process improvements.

Development

All public repos can be foundÂ here.

Zen testnet

We will be reaching out and partnering with long-time hosts to increase the available storage on the testnet. Software downloads for the Zen Testnet version of siad are now available here. A testnet explorer and siacoin faucet are liveÂ here.

mainnet

core

Weâ€™re back with the State of Sia, a monthly installment looking at development and team updates for The Sia Foundation.

Welcome to 2023! A new year always stirs excitement for the future and reflection at what was accomplished the year prior. For an individual, it might be time to make that resolution a reality. For an organization, itâ€™s time to re-align on goals and get ready for another year of forward progress.

When I joined the Foundation, there were just a few months left in 2022. Even within my short time here, Iâ€™m incredibly proud to see how much weâ€™ve grown. Hereâ€™s a highlight reel of a few notable things the Foundation did throughout lastÂ year:

  • got listed on Web3Index
  • released Embarcadero, a tool for conducting escrowless Siafund/Siacoin swaps
  • completely redesigned sia.tech
  • released Sia v1.5.8 andÂ v1.5.9
  • launched the Grants Program, and approved four of the eight initial proposals
  • brought on three new hires from Skynet LabsÂ (hi!)
  • and most importantly, made lots of progress on our new apps for Siaâ€Šâ€”â€Šrenterd, hostd, andÂ walletd

We made pretty big strides in terms of our development focus and organizational structure, and we intend to carry this into the new year. Before I get ahead of myself though, letâ€™s take a walk through specific work done in the month of December.

Development

All public repos can be foundÂ here.

core

The core repo is currently public and can be foundÂ here.

We implemented a modernized version of Siaâ€™s consensus code. This will make syncing much faster, enable blockchain pruning, and greatly ease the transition to Utreexo. This code has not been merged yet; first, we need to run the new version alongside the old version while processing the entire blockchain, to ensure there are no discrepancies between theÂ two.

Relevant code isÂ here.

renterd

renterd will be our new stand-alone renter. The renterd repo is currently public and can be foundÂ here.

We worked on getting uploads, downloads, automatic contract formations and renewals (all functions of the autopilot) working in production and beyond our integration tests to allow for more expansive testing.

  • Implemented upload + download HTTP endpoints in renterd, with support for range requests.
Note from Luke: Range requests are a feature of HTTP APIs that allows you to download â€œrangesâ€ of data within a file, rather than having to download the entire thing. Itâ€™s a pretty basic feature, but an important one.
  • Added price gouging checks, though not quite finished. Although thatâ€™s not 100% finishedÂ yet
  • Next step is migrations (dataÂ repair)

hostd

hostd is the app youâ€™ll be using to rent out your excess storage space to the SiaÂ network.

  • Migrated API to SiaFoundation/jape, add missing endpoints fromÂ spec
  • Replaced us in integration tests withÂ renterd
  • Added payout transactions to SingleAddressWallet
  • Replaced remaining ephemeral stores with SQLiteÂ stores
  • Replaced consensus module with chainÂ manager

walletd

walletd will be the place to store your Siacoins.

We ultimately decided not to go with the bitcoin coin selection algorithm because, after writing some simulation code, we found it was not much better from a fee minimization perspective than the random algorithm.

skyrecover

skyrecover is a set of utilities to recover lost skyd data. The skyrecover repo is currently public and can be foundÂ here.

  • Created a tool to search hosts for lost sectors using the Skynet fileÂ metadata
  • Created a tool to download lost sectors from hosts using the Skynet fileÂ metadata

Web/website

The Sia Network Hosting Best Practices document has been added to the website. The Sia Foundation has prepared this document to provide high level guidance for using the Sia network. Our goal in doing so is not to provide legal advice, but to establish a set of common best practices for Hosts. This will help ensure the continued efficient functioning of the Sia network and enable Hosts and Renters alike to continue to realize its benefits.

The Sia Foundation suggests that all Hosts know and follow these best practices. Please also check back to review these best practices, as we may update them from time toÂ time.

We have updated the grants page to be a little more specific, and will soon add more useful information such as an FAQÂ section.

Web/renterd

We continued work on the renterd app and integrating the new bus and autopilot APIs across all features.

We built a React library for interacting with renterd's new bus and autopilot APIs. The library is a set of fully typed React hooks for fetching data and making mutations. The library will release along with the renterd app, and will be a convenient option for any developers looking to build UIs with the renterdÂ APIs.

Team Updates

Our three newest hires have all settled into their new roles nicely. Chris and PJ found their footing immediately and set to work on various renterd tasks. I know the team really appreciates having more highly experienced Sia devs to share ideas and workload as we develop these powerful newÂ apps.

I hope the Ops team is as happy about me joining the team as I am to be here! Weâ€™ve set to work on a few important things, like enacting new policies for the team and taking over project management for the Grants Program. My aim is always to help an organization marry efficiency and compassion, and Iâ€˜m proud to be part of a team here at the Foundation that strives for theseÂ goals.

Other Foundation Happenings

Advent ofÂ Code

Advent of Code presented a month of fun challenges, and weâ€™re thankful to all participants. As mentioned last month, any participant who completed seven or more days will receive a prize from the team. Weâ€™ll have an announcement regarding the prize this week or early next. If you qualify, keep an eye on the #announcements channel in our Discord server for moreÂ info.

Quarterly Report

The Q4 2022 Transparency Report has been published! These updates are an important part of the transparency that we promote, giving our community insight into our highlighted work, financials, and futureÂ plans.

And remember, you can always check out our previous updates over on ourÂ website.

Grants Program

Weâ€™re really pleased with how the Grants Program performed in 2022. The committee reviewed a total of eight proposals and approved four, and weâ€™re excited to see how these projects develop over the comingÂ year.

Remember to check blog.sia.tech to find out the latest grant happenings.

If you think youâ€™ve got a great idea to benefit the Sia ecosystem, submit your proposal over at forum.sia.tech.

Thatâ€™s allÂ folks

From everyone here at the Foundation, thank you for a wonderful 12 months, and thank you for your continued support. The new year sees us refreshed, with a larger team, and on the brink of releasing some of the most significant software the Sia network has everÂ seen.

Until nextÂ time!

Weâ€™re back with the State of Sia, a monthly installment looking at development and team updates for The Sia Foundation.

We hope youâ€™ve been well since our last update. The penultimate month of 2022 was filled with progress as we worked on major initiatives and welcomed new team members. Youâ€™ll hear about bothÂ shortly!

The first of these updates released last month and was received quite well in the community. We were incredibly pleased to see that. We want to better communicate the progress we make, and it seems like this update is shaping up to be a great first step towards thatÂ goal.

We could also print out the code and send it to you, but weâ€™ll stick with this method forÂ now.

Development

renterd

renterd will be our new stand-alone renter.

Significant progress continues on the new renterd. A meeting of the minds for the three developers involved resulted in an architectural overhaul of the app. renterd will now consist of three components: worker, bus, and autopilot (names could change). Here's the PR, and hereâ€™s theÂ tl;dr:

bus is the source of the truth for the stuff, worker does the stuff, and autopilot makes all the stuff happen easily. â€œStuffâ€ in this case of course being the litany of contract formations, blockchain checking, downloads, and other work that any particular instance of Sia used for renting mustÂ do.

This architecture allows renterd to scale horizontally (important for third party use), and will let our devs work mostly independently as they each tackle a component.

renterd also saw continued work on its UI, primarily related to the new autopilot system, and designing it into the host and contracts features.

Some specific bits added to autopilot this month included:

  • an initial autopilot loop
  • a contractor
  • a hostÂ scanner
  • host filtering andÂ scoring
  • migrated the backend (object store, contract store and hostdb) over to a SQLÂ database
  • currently working on object repairs in the autopilot
  • building a test suite for integration tests

For worker, contributions were made to hostÂ metrics.

hostd

hostd is the app youâ€™ll be using to rent out your excess storage space to the SiaÂ network.

  • Refactored the financial manager
  • Fixed accounting issues related to ephemeral accounts
  • Refactored the MDMÂ executor
  • Added financial tracking to all income sources for RHP2 andÂ RHP3
  • Migrated financial store and contract metadata store to SQLite from BadgerDB. Tested a wallet store withÂ SQLite.
  • Added integration tests for financials
  • Additional consistency tests for siadÂ renters

skyrecover

skyrecover is a set of utilities to recover lost skydÂ data.

  • Fix issue recovering smallÂ files
  • Added tool to scan base sectors for a specificÂ checksum

walletd

walletd will be the place to store your Siacoins.

We worked on making the jape API checker more robust. These checks prevent a common developer error where more than one HTTP response isÂ sent.

This PR added the bitcoin coin selection and the single random draw selection algorithm to the walletd rewrite. Weâ€™re now working on simulating past transactions to see which algorithm is more efficient in terms of minimizing fees.

web

We refactored styling across the Sia design system and apps, migrating all code to Tailwind, a popular CSS framework. Tailwindâ€™s widespread use amongst developers will make future contributions to Siaâ€™s UI code easier. We also updated the website to be more optimized for mobile layouts (and other minor updates to content).

Team Updates

Chris joined the team in November! To say this is a great pick up for the Foundation is an understatement. Coming from Skynet Labs, Chris has been working on Sia for longer than anyone except for Siaâ€™s co-founders Luke and David. He brings intimate knowledge of the codebase and wonderful new ideas to theÂ team.

Hereâ€™s what Luke had to say about Chris joining the Sia Foundation.

We have another exciting addition to announce: Chris has joined the Foundation! Chris really needs no introduction; he discovered Sia in the early days of the project, and has been making enormously valuable contributions ever since, spanning nearly the entire codebase. Needless to say, Iâ€™m very pleased to have him aboard to lend his experience and passion to renterd, Utreexo, and beyond. Welcome!Â :)
- Luke Champine, President and Core Developer of The Sia Foundation

This is our last new hire for 2022. With three recent pick ups to add to an already excellent team, the Sia Foundation is well-positioned to rocket intoÂ 2023.

Other Foundation Happenings
